content.description:
In a laboratory population of fruit flies, body color is determined by a single gene with a wild-type allele associated with black body color and a mutant allele associated with yellow body color. A group of researchers hypothesizes that the mutation in fruit flies that causes the yellow body is sex-linked. They also hypothesize that this mutation results in a change in the structure of the sex combs, bristle-like structures on the front legs of male flies that facilitate mating.

To determine the inheritance pattern of the mutant allele, researchers crossed yellow-bodied females with wild-type males. Flies from the <math alttext="F 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> generation were then crossed. The distribution of phenotypes observed in the <math alttext="F 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="F 2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> generations is shown in Table 1.
